title: LCD Screen and 3x4 Matrix Keypad with NodeMCU ESP32
description: Basics of wiring and using an I2C LCD and a 3x4 matrix keypad with a NodeMCU ESP32.

questions.prompt: Which two signal lines are used by an I2C LCD to communicate with the ESP32?
questions.explanation: I2C uses two lines: SDA (data) and SCL (clock).

questions.prompt: A 3x4 matrix keypad has 7 pins because it is wired as:
questions.explanation: A 3x4 keypad has 4 row lines and 3 column lines, totaling 7 pins.

questions.prompt: How do you typically detect which key is pressed on a matrix keypad?
choices: Scan rows one at a time and read the columns
Use an I2C address to read key values
Power each key with a separate battery
questions.explanation: Matrix keypads are scanned by driving rows and reading columns to find the intersection.

questions.prompt: Why is key debouncing needed when reading a keypad?
choices: To prevent multiple false presses from a single physical press
To increase the ESP32 clock speed
questions.explanation: Mechanical keys can bounce, causing multiple rapid on/off signals.

questions.prompt: Which statement about ESP32 logic levels is safest when wiring peripherals?
choices: ESP32 uses 3.3V logic, so avoid feeding 5V signals directly to GPIO
ESP32 GPIO pins always require 5V to work
questions.explanation: ESP32 GPIOs are 3.3V logic. Feeding higher voltages can damage the chip.
